unnormalised: **Is adaptive learning really the future of EdTech?**
normalised: Is adaptive learning really the future of EdTech?

unnormalised: Okay, so I've been hearing a lot about adaptive learning lately. It sounds pretty cool – like a personal tutor that actually *gets* what you're struggling with. Basically, from what I understand, it's using tech to tailor the learning experience to each student's individual needs. Think of it like this: instead of everyone in class going at the same pace, like in those old-school Doon School classrooms, the software figures out what you know and what you don't, and then adjusts the difficulty level accordingly.

unnormalised: My cousin, Priya, who teaches Maths in a CBSE school in Lucknow, was telling me how they're piloting some adaptive learning programs. She says it's really helping the weaker students catch up, while also keeping the brighter ones challenged. No more boredom!

unnormalised: But honestly, is it just hype? I mean, will it really replace teachers completely? I doubt it. A good teacher, like Mrs. Sharma who taught us English back in 2008 (wow, time flies!), can't be replaced by an algorithm. She understood *us*, not just the curriculum.
normalised: But honestly, is it just hype? I mean, will it really replace teachers completely? I doubt it. A good teacher, like Missus Sharma who taught us English back in two thousand and eight (wow, time flies!), can't be replaced by an algorithm. She understood us, not just the curriculum.

unnormalised: Also, what about access? How do we make sure every kid in India, even those in remote villages with patchy internet, gets access to this? It can't just be a privilege for the folks in Delhi and Mumbai.
